content: chore: adaptations for nightly-2024-11-28 #19589 Please review this PR. At the end of the month this diff will land in .

@Sébastien Gouëzel, I needed to make some changes on nightly-testing after your #18849 landed. Would you mind taking a quick look at https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/e279b931a6f354a7ccb90b2f673dc432a4888c53, and let me know whether you think this is acceptable.

I'm a guessing this is due to the slight weakening of unification after Kyle fixed the nasty bug in lean#6024 (which, sadly, despite being wrong, was actually helping with unification problems).

We are hoping to "power up" unification again to compensate, but it won't be able to happen immediately.

So the question here is really -- is this an acceptable regression in Mathlib, and if not, can we do redesign in Mathlib right now to deal with it?

Relatedly, I had to make the change in https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/7e4ff11d314feb92007de2f661c17ff0762642ce, after @Yury G. Kudryashov's #19445, for I think the same reason.
Thank you! Does it mean we should make more arguments explicit in Mathlib or wait for the "power up"?

I'm not surprised at all: in this file, there are several places where one already needed to add extra information (see for instance the proof of docs#MDifferentiableWithinAt.clm_comp), so it seems completely reasonable that it is needed more uniformly. Not even sure adaptation notes are needed since it's fixing a previous bug.

Yury G. Kudryashov said:

Thank you! Does it mean we should make more arguments explicit in Mathlib or wait for the "power up"?

We're going to have to add to hints (typically, filling in implicit arguments manually) in the meantime. Overall on mathlib is hasn't been too bad, I think we just got unlucky today.
I think for now I'll leave in the adaptation notes, as they are good breadcrumbs for testing future improvements.
